huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Pine Valley, Virgin River unit has a small population of sheep numbering approximately 100 sheep.  Most years there are only two ram permits on for this hunt.  This is a shared population on with Arizona and the hunt coincides with Arizona's hunt.  Their is a lot of movement of sheep across the state line.  There are no developed camp grounds in this area. Camping on BLM land is limited to 14 days in any one location.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: As with most sheep habitat the terrain is extremely rugged.  Make sure you are ready physically and have good hiking boots. Cell phone service is spotty.  Make sure friends and family know where you are hunting and when to expect you to return. Carry plenty of water.  Day time temps are still very warm for this November-December hunt time frame. Hunting in pairs is a good idea.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: Day time temps area still into the 70's, expect the night time low's down into the 20-30's.  Occasional short rain showers are possible.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 100~125~250 (Virgin River/Beaver Dam)~~~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES: Sheep can be found 91 in the Scrub Peak, Cedar Pockets and Bull dog Canyon area.  Make sure you have good optics.  Setting up at key vantage points and glassing large chunks of country should help you find pockets of sheep to set up stocks on. You can expect to find rams in the 150-160 class.  Several 165 rams have been harvested over the past ten years.   Landownership in the this area is almost 100% BLM lands.  You will be hunting along the Utah/Arizona state line and it is not marked in any way.  Use a GPS and land marks to know where you are in relation to the state line at all times.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: After harvesting a bighorn sheep, you must bring the horns to a DWR office within 72 hours of leaving your hunting area. Checking in a bighorn sheep will fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement. If you received a bighorn sheep permit and did not hunt or did not harvest, you must complete your harvest survey online or by calling toll-free 1-800-221-0659 within 30 days of the season end date printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you being unable to apply for big game permits in subsequent years.

huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: There are not any developed campground on the sub-unit.  The nearest developed campground is located at Gunlock State Park.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: Stay on existing roads and trails. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and the Dixie National Forest and are covered on their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to BLM and USFS.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Washington Countyâ€”Boundary begins at SR-18 and I-15 in St. George; northwest on SR-18 to US-91; southwest on US-91 to the Arizona-Utah state line; east along this state line to I-15; north on I-15 to St. George. USGS 1:100,000 Map: Saint George. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.
